title: Authors and Citation
text: Liu Z (2024). Linkage: Package (Title Case). R package version 2.1.0, https://aicplane.github.io/Linkage/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {Linkage: What the Package Does (Title Case)},   author = {Zenghui Liu},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 2.1.0},   url = {https://aicplane.github.io/Linkage/}, }

title: What the Package Does (Title Case)
text: Linkage user-friendly, interactive, open-source R-Shiny web application exploring visualizing potential gene cis-regulatory elements (CREs) based ATAC-seq RNA-seq data. Users can upload customized data  re-analysis public datasets, obtain genome-wide CREs simple clicks. CREs predicted multi-omics sequencing data, rather experimentally determined. main feature Linkage identify potential CREs whole genome performing canonical correlation analysis quantitative chromatin accessibility measure quantitative expression level across samples. Additional modules developed allow users perform systematic deeper analysis gene regulatory landscape. Shiny application additionally hosted https://xulabgdpu.org.cn/linkage. Data input TCGA Breast Cancer cohort dataset contains chromatin accessibility gene expression data  72 patients breast cancer. chromatin accessibility data normalized bulk ATAC-seq count matrix, prior count 5 added raw counts, put “counts per million”, log2 transformed, quantile normalized.  gene expression data normalized bulk RNA-seq count matrix, log2(fpkm+1) transformed. GSE121589 dataset contains chromatin accessibility gene expression data  33 mice Muscle Stem Cells (MuSCs). chromatin accessibility data normalized bulk ATAC-seq count matrix, prior count 5 added raw counts, put “counts per million”, log2 transformed, quantile normalized.  gene expression data normalized bulk RNA-seq count matrix, log2(fpkm+1) transformed. Two tab-delimited text/csv input files (chromatin accessibility matrix gene expression matrix) required running Linkage. gene expression matrix file tab-delimited multi-column data matrix, first column represents gene symbols following columns represent normalized raw expression levels genes sample. chromatin accessibility matrix file tab-delimited multi-column data matrix well, first three columns represent chromosome name, start coordinate chromosome end coordinate chromosome peaks respectively; remaining columns chromatin accessibility matrix file represent normalized raw chromatin accessibility levels peaks sample.  element  ready--analysis files appear Chromatin Accessibility Matrix panel Gene Expression Matrix panel.  Regulatory Peaks Search Module Regulatory Peaks Search Module allows users detect potential regulatory DNA regions specific genes. given input gene targeting DNA regions, Linkage automatically perform canonical correlation analysis quantitative chromatin accessibility measure region quantitative expression level gene across samples. Users can easily adjust region interest customize correlation algorithm (Spearman / Pearson / Kendall). ,  statistically significant results  listed  Potential Cis-regulatory Regions panel.  clicking  specific region panel, users can view scatter plot quantitative chromatin accessibility gene expression Correlation Plot panel. rho FDR correlation analysis also shown scatter plot.  Regulatory Peaks Visualization Module Regulatory Peaks Visualization Module allows users visualize coverage mapped ATAC-seq reads around given specific regulatory peak, well corresponding quantitative expression target gene regulatory peak. Users initially select regulatory peak obtained Regulatory Peaks Detection Module. Linkage categorizes samples five groups based quantitative chromatin accessibility  specific regulatory peak, ranging low high individual sample. coverage track mapped ATAC-seq reads boxplot target gene group shown simultaneously.  Regulatory Peaks Annotation Module Regulatory Peaks Annotation Module allows users visualize annotation predicational regulatory peaks Linkage. users click ‘Annotate Regulatory Peaks’, Linkage perform annotation  predicational regulatory peaks terms genomic location features, includes whether peak TSS, Exon, 5’ UTR, 3’ UTR, Intronic Intergenic  position strand information nearest gene peaks. effectively visualize overlaps distribution annotation peaks, Linkage also produces upsetplot adopting ChIPseeker package.  Motif Analysis Module Motif Analysis Module supports users visualize enriched transcription factor motifs within potential regulatory peaks. clicking  specific peak, users can view location binding score information enriched transcription factor region. users select one transcription factors, corresponding sequence logo cis-regulatory element appear Sequence-logo Plot panel.  Regulatory Network Module Regulatory Network Module helps users  visualize GRNs  nodes genes corresponding cis-regulatory elements，inferred previous analysis Linkage. First, users can input list interested genes  upload  gene-list file obtained previous analysis.  users can adjust series parameters related building GRN, including types  gene symbols, calculation methods thresholds  interactions nodes (edges GRNs). users click ‘Build Network’, Linkage perform canonical correlation analysis quantitative expression level  interested gene  potential cis-regulatory elements. significant calculation results  correlation analysis  shown  Gene-TF Table panel. Meanwhile, Linkage produces corresponding informatic interactive GRN adopting visNetwork package. Users can easily change network layouts, select subnetworks, save GRN spreadsheets interaction score plots.  Pathway Enrichment Module Pathway Enrichment Module supports users visualize tabular graphical pathway enrichment results interested gene lists, can produced previous analysis Linkage.  enrichment analysis can link gene lists underlying molecular pathways functional categories gene ontology (GO) Kyoto Encyclopedia Genes Genomes (KEGG).
code: if (!requireNamespace("devtools", quietly = TRUE))   install.packages("devtools")  devtools::install_github("aicplane/Linkage") library(Linkage) Install.biocViews() Linkage()

title: Regulate peak genomic location browsing boxplot — box_plot
Regulate peak genomic location browsing boxplot — box_plot
code: peakfile.dir <- system.file("extdata","ENSG00000000419.csv", package = "Linkage") peakfile <- read.csv(peakfile.dir, header = T,check.names = F) gene.dir <- system.file("extdata","TCGA-BRCA-RNA.txt", package = "Linkage") gene <- data.table::fread(gene.dir, header = T,check.names = F) gene <- gene[gene$ensembl_gene_id == "ENSG00000000419", ] p <- trackplot(peakfile = peakfile, 1, "Homo")  box_plot(peakfile, gene, select_peak = 1, F) #>                      gene  group #> TCGA-A2-A0EX-01A 19.06652 group1 #> TCGA-A2-A0T5-01A 19.04901 group1 #> what: Finding the regulatory peak of genes — regulatory_peak
title: Finding the regulatory peak of genes — regulatory_peak
Finding the regulatory peak of genes — regulatory_peak
code: regulatory_peak(RNA.seq, ATAC.seq, range, cor_method)

title: Finding the regulatory peak of genes — regulatory_peak
text: RNA.seq Expression single multiple genes ATAC.seq ATAC-Seq Expression Matrix range Expand range genes find regulatory peaks cor_method correlation calculation, pearson/spearman/kendall can selected

title: Finding the regulatory peak of genes — regulatory_peak
Finding the regulatory peak of genes — regulatory_peak
code: RNA.seq.dir <- system.file("extdata","TCGA-BRCA-RNA.txt", package = "Linkage") RNA.seq <- data.table::fread(RNA.seq.dir, header = T)[c(1:10), ] position.dir <- system.file("extdata","homo.gene_positions.plus.txt", package = "Linkage") position <- data.table::fread(position.dir, header = T, sep = "\t") RNA.seq <- merge(position, RNA.seq, by.x = "ensembl_gene_id", by.y = "ensembl_gene_id") Homo.list.files.dir <- system.file("extdata","Homo.ATAC", package = "Linkage") Homo.list.files <- list.files(Homo.list.files.dir) Homo.list.files <- paste0(Homo.list.files.dir,"/", Homo.list.files) Homo.df_list <- lapply(Homo.list.files, function(file) data.table::fread(file, header = T)) ATAC.seq <- do.call(rbind, Homo.df_list) regulatory_peak(RNA.seq, ATAC.seq, 500000, "spearman") #> Error in `$<-.data.frame`(x, name, value): replacement has 0 rows, data has 32

title: Enrichment analysis Upsetplot — upsetplot
code: extdatadir <- system.file("extdata", "Senescence-associated secretory phenotype.txt", package = "Linkage") gene_list <- read.table(extdatadir) go <- GO.enrichment(gene_list = gene_list$V1, Species = "Homo", genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name") #> Warning: cannot open compressed file '', probable reason 'Invalid argument' #> Error in readChar(con, 5L, useBytes = TRUE): cannot open the connection upsetplot(go) #> Error in h(simpleError(msg, call)): error in evaluating the argument 'x' in selecting a method for function 'upsetplot': object 'go' not found

code: dir <- system.file("extdata","ENSG00000000419.csv", package = "Linkage") peakfile <- read.csv(dir, header = T) peakAnno <- Peak_Annottation(peakfile, Species = "Homo") #> >> preparing features information...		 2024-02-21 13:44:33  #> >> identifying nearest features...		 2024-02-21 13:44:33  #> >> calculating distance from peak to TSS...	 2024-02-21 13:44:34  #> >> assigning genomic annotation...		 2024-02-21 13:44:34  #> >> adding gene annotation...			 2024-02-21 13:44:36  #> 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns #> >> assigning chromosome lengths			 2024-02-21 13:44:36  #> >> done...					 2024-02-21 13:44:36  vennpie(peakAnno)
